title: 107_s869
content:
The Children's Act for Responsible Employment of 2001, also known as the CARE Act, references the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. Section 2 of the Act pertains to agricultural employment. The CARE Act, referencing the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, amends Section 13(c) regarding agricultural employment. It exempts certain employees in agriculture from child labor provisions if employed by family members on their farm. Additionally, it removes paragraphs (2) and (4) and addresses civil and criminal penalties for child labor violations. The CARE Act amends Section 16 of the Fair Labor Standards Act, increasing civil money penalties to $15,000 and adding a minimum penalty of $500. It also introduces penalties for violations resulting in serious bodily injury, illness, or death, allowing legal action against employers in such cases. The CARE Act amends Section 16 of the Fair Labor Standards Act to increase civil money penalties and introduce penalties for violations resulting in serious bodily harm or death. Legal action can be taken against employers in such cases, with provisions for attorney's fees and costs to be paid by the defendant. Recovery obtained under this subsection can be offset against State worker's compensation laws. The CARE Act amends Section 16 of the Fair Labor Standards Act to impose criminal penalties for violations related to oppressive child labor, including fines up to $15,000 and imprisonment up to 5 years for willful or repeat violations resulting in harm to minor employees. The amendments do not override state laws offering greater protections for employees. SEC. 4. REPORTING AND RECORD-KEEPING. Section 12 (29 U.S.C. 212) is amended to require the Secretary and the Director of the Bureau of the Census to compile biannual data on industries and occupations where children under 18 are employed, as well as cases of child employment violations. Employers must report any injuries or illnesses of individuals under 18 to the State employment security agency. The Secretary and the Director of the Bureau of the Census compile biannual data on industries and occupations where children under 18 are employed, including cases of child employment violations. Employers must report injuries or illnesses of individuals under 18 to the State employment security agency. Beginning January 1, 2003, a biannual report on child labor in the United States and its safety and health hazards will be issued by the Secretary in conjunction with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 5. COORDINATION.

The Secretary will work closely with non-governmental organizations, State, and local government agencies to enforce labor and safety laws. State and local agencies will provide injury and death information to the Secretary for enforcement purposes. The Secretary may reimburse these agencies for their services.

SEC. 6. REGULATIONS. SEC. 6. REGULATIONS.

The Secretary of Labor must issue regulations within a specified timeframe to implement this Act and its amendments. The regulations will become effective within a certain number of days after being issued.
